headline: Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies
description: These sugar-free peanut butter cookies are gluten free too. With just three simple ingredients you can satisfy your sweet tooth with no sugar.
name: Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies
recipeIngredient: 2 cups granular no-calorie sucralose sweetener (e.g., Splenda ®)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with a silicone liner.
Mix peanut butter, sucralose, and eggs together in a bowl until thoroughly combined. Drop by spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet.
Bake in the preheated oven until the centers appear dry, about 8 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Made these because I am diabetic. With no flour, they don’t bake like a cookie and are way too sweet. Plus, when you pick them up they fall apart. Very disappointing.

These cookies are yummy. No sugar, no flour, not your Grandma's PB cookie recipe. I used 3/4 C of Splenda which is sweet enough for me. Also added 1/2 C quick oats and 1 T vanilla. No matter how good they smell, leave them be on the cooling rack for an hour unless you want crumbles. Once they set up, they will stack and store just fine. I used 1/4 C scoop dropper to form and drop the dough. Only makes 9 cookies that way, so went 15 min at 350. You can see from the pic that I forked them flat and you can see they really do not spread. So if you drop them and do not flatten, they will retain their shape and not cook properly.

I also made these for my 84 year old father who had recently been diagnosed with diabetes. I read the reviews and, knowing oatmeal helps maintain glucose levels and can be beneficial to diabetics, added 3/4 cup of dry oatmeal. I substituted 1 cup Splenda BROWN sugar for 1 cup of the Splenda white sugar. Fearing the oatmeal might make the cookies too dry, I used extra large/jumbo eggs and I added 1/2 tsp vanilla simply for flavor. Not only did my dad love these cookies, my mom, my whole family, including grandchildren LOVED these cookies. This recipe, with my changes, made 32-36 silver dollar size cookies. The natural peanut butter isn't cheap and we limit sugar substitutes for our kids, so in our family, this is pretty much an adult cookie and the kids get real cookies.

I am on prednisone so I have to watch my sugar intake for 90 days. I googled sugar free cookie recipes and this came up. I read through several reviews before making these cookies. Here's what I came up with:

I used crunchy peanut butter. It added a nice taste and texture to this recipe. I only made a half batch since I wasn't sure if I'd like them or not. 

I added 1/2 cup of oats
1/2 tsp of vanilla extract
20 packets of splenda (it was sweet and good but next time I'll only do 15 packets). I use packets so I can tweak until I find a nice level of sweetness that I like. 

I put a tablespoon amount in my hand and squeezed the dough until they were tight (they were sort of falling apart so I squeezed them to make sure there were no cracks in the dough. I think this helped with the crumbling others spoke about when making these cookies). I rolled into balls and put them on parchment paper. I used a fork to spread them out and do the criss-cross pattern. I baked them for 8 minutes and let them sit while I did my homework. I came back later and they were fine. They didn't crumble and fall apart like others said in their reviews. They were a little dry, but not too bad. They were still good and this is coming from someone who usually cooks with sugar. 

I hope this helps!
These are wonderful for me wanting to lower my sugar intake and my husband is a diabetic. I added vanilla and cocoa for chocolate peanut butter cookies. Mmmm.
My pops loves it. Maybe half the amount of Splenda. Too artificial sweet, I think.
Taste as good as the real thing . I scored with a fork the second time I made them just to give them a nicer look.

I was looking for a recipe for a grandson who loves my baking but he was diagnosed with Diabetes so i wanted him to enjoy my baking that would not hurt him. these turned out great and were a hit with the grandson .
for a sugar-free cookie, I loved this cookie! I only added one cup sweetener and I added a cup of oatmeal and 1 teaspoon vanilla (per someone else's suggestion) turned out great

I used 1 cup of stevia and 2 cups of Jif extra crunchy and a dash of vanilla with 2 eggs. Baked for 10 mins at 350 as a drop cookie mashed down with a fork. Let them cool and they are really great. Adding Oatmeal will add carbs so I didn't do it. They are crumbly but better by far than NO cookie!

These cookies are delicious! I tried all the things that people said to try in their other reviews. I added a third a cup of oats, a teaspoon of vanilla, a splash of milk, and a tablespoon of cocoa. The Coco Gave great flavor and made the cookie slightly darker. The one thing I didn't do is add less Splenda. The cookies were a little crumbly, but not much. By adding only one and a half cups of Splenda would've helped with this. What also helped with the crumbliness is making the cookie smaller. My cookies a tablespoon in size. All in all this was an amazing recipe that tastes amazing too. All you have to do is tweak it slightly.

I have food sensitivities so these gluten free peanut butter cookies are a fabulous option for me! I also have food sensitivities to eggs, dairy, and sugar cane. As such I had to make a few adjustments to these. I used a Vegan egg replacer that I found at my local grocery store. I used Earth Balance creamy peanut butter because it is sweetened with Agave instead of sugar cane or sugar cane derived products (i.e. molasses). The last thing I added was some vanilla extract and about 1/4 cup of unsweetened maple peanut butter just to add a bit of a different flavor and because the Earth Balance was extremely thick vs the maple which was more oily and helped to incorporate all of the ingredients more evenly. These cookies came out AMAZING! I am not someone that just says something is amazing, as a former culinary arts connoisseur and someone very new to all of these food sensitivity issues, I need my food to have a lot of robust and vibrant flavors. These cookies are a life saver for me because they help curb my sweet cravings when I am unable to have much else.

I made these cookies adding the 3/4 cup oatmeal and 1 tsp vanilla and reducing sweetener (I used Truvia) to 1/2 cup, as suggested by another reviewer. I also used chunky peanut butter. You do have to cool the cookies completely before eating, otherwise they will crumble in your hand. Even after they cool completely, they are still a bit more crumbly than traditional cookies. Best to eat them over a plate or napkin.

The small amount I was able to get into my mouth was not tasty at all and was very gritty. Very disappointed. :-(

I used Trivia sweetener. I find it to taste most like the real thing. I am also a Diabetic so whenever a recipe calls for ap flour like maybe 2 cups, I'll put 11/2 cup Whole Wheat flour and 1/2 cup ap flour, this reduces the carbs from the ap flour.

I used almond butter instead of peanut butter due to a diet I'm on. I used Stevia and also added vanilla. 
I was skeptical, so I halfed the recipe. They taste much better than expected....i was pleasantly surprised!

Cookies were delicious; but so fragile that they could not be stored. In hindsight, I wonder what brand of natural peanut butter was used for the development of this recipe; because they vary alot in consistency and ingredients. 

Also, for those who found the recipe too sweet, many peanut butters labeled "natural" still have extra sugar in them, just no additives; so that will affect the taste quite a bit.

For diabetics, a sugarless recipe with flour and levening in it would be much better; but my interest was for an Atkins, or low-carb, version.
Love, love, love this just let cool before removing from cookie sheet.

I have made these cookies many many times ... they are wonderful! Now ... the folks that have had problems with them falling apart ... LET THEM COOL COMPLETLY ... they will firm up. I also add flaxseed ... about 2 tbsp. And if you are still having problems with them firming up ... add an extra egg white. At Christmas time I push a dark chocolate kiss in the middle ... the dark chocolate still keeps them low carb

I just made these and they are crumbly even when they are cool off. I will try again later just in case I screwed up. They do have a good taste.

We also added the tsp of vanilla which adds a lot of flavor and some of the liquid you need to get the batter smooth. It's true that they are a little soft and don't stay together as well as traditional cookies but the taste and ease of baking well makes up for that!

These are simply amazing! I've had Gastric bypass and have always had a bit of a sweet tooth and these hit the spot without me worrying if I'm going to end up in pain. They're warm and a bit gooey when warm, but once they cool they'll be amazing! I'm thinking of rolling in some rolled oats and some vanilla next time around! Can't wait to make these for my mini-me!

Loved it! I hate artificial sweeteners but you really can not taste it in these cookies once cooked. Sidenote: I did use 1 1/2 cups of splenda though and not 2 cups. I also added 2tsp of vanilla extract. These will satisfy my sweet cravings as I'm on a strict no sugar diet.

The texture wasnt so bad either, a little crumbles on my plate but not anything major.. devoured three cookies in 3 minutes..yummm!

Terrific and easy recipe though.

I tried this recipe and love it. However I added a tsp of vanilla and 1/4 cup of oatmeal. I used dry splenda sweetener which caused the cookies to ooze on the parchment paper in the oven but didn't change the outcome. I added 5 minutes to the bake time. I also added a few Tblsp of water as I mixed it. It was stiff, really stiff but after the few spoons of water it mixed really well. Let them cool completely before eating or storing. I read where these crumbled easy. Well to cure that store them on a paper towel in the container and they will stay soft till gone. They remind me of no bake cookies without the sugar. 
Lets see, no sugar and low carbs. Yup I will fix these again.

Sugar free recipes with a good texture are hard to find. These are wonderful. I used only 2/3 cup Pure Via. I put the jar of pb in the microwave for 30 seconds to soften it a bit. I used lower fat pb, and it tastes great. I also added the tsp. vanilla and a shake of nutmeg. I baked them for 10 min.

I made these for my grandmother. I didn't have enough splenda so I did use sugar, however they still turned out amazing. Great for those who don't eat gluten and she didn't even notice there was no flour in them! I guess I make smaller cookies because I got well over 24. Next time I'll have to prepare ahead of time and make them sugar free. Remember to let the cookies sit for a few minutes when you take them out of the oven and they won't be crumbly.
Love it with the crunchy peanut butter. I make them sometimes about the size of a peanut without the crisscross and call them "peanut butter poppers"
i'm going to make some for my sweetheart :)
Tasted too much like Splenda. I was disappointed.
I didn't like them but my dad did, they are for him since he's a diabetic so I suppose thats all that matters!!! So thank you. (:

I just made these and they are terrific. I used 1 cup of crunchy and 1 cup of creamy all natural/organic p'butter. Since Sucralose is really bad for you, I used 1 cup of natural Stevia instead. I also added the recommended 1 tsp of vanilla, 1/2 cup of natural oatmeal and cooked for 10 minutes. To avoid the dryness, I added 2 tbs of milk to the recipe. After 5 minutes of cooling on the cookie sheet and 15 minutes on the cooling rack, they were good to go - no crumbling. I definitely miss the brown sugar, so I think I will add a bit of cinnamon or other sugar free flavor next time.
These cookies tasted good however need to add an extra egg for high altitude. First batch was like loose flour. Second batch added an extra egg and then it turned out fine.
These were very good and my kids loved them! I added the 3/4 cup oatmeal and the 1 tsp vanilla extract.

I've made these multiple times and here's what I've found out. The sugar substitute mellows after a day or two. I mix Splenda, Nutri Sweet and Sweet-n-low, instead of using just one type of sweetener. (An old Atkins trick to cut down on the after taste.) The last time I made these, I added about 4 heaping tablespoons of unsweetened apple sauce, and instead of rolling them, made them into drop cookies. I also cooked them longer - 12 minutes. (because of the apple sauce, they will leach water during the baking process, so be prepared with a paper towel) Store them in a cookie jar so that they don't lose their crunchy chewy outer texture. This was the best batch so far.
